Lady the Member for Leeds, South-East that that is not enough, and that is why we have put on the Statute book the House Purchase and Housing Act. I endorse what my hon. Friend the Member for the City of Chester (Mr. Temple) said about the importance of these grants being made use of, and I am sure that I can rely upon the hon. Lady, and, indeed, upon hon. Members on both sides of the Committee, for support—for part of that Bill has had all-party support—to do everything they can to publicise the new standard grants scheme and get it used to the full.

The whole basis of my argument and that of my hon. Friend the Member for Stoke-on-Trent, North (Mrs. Slater) was that even though we represent those cities where landlords have been entitled to use these improvement grants hardly anything has been done.

That is why we have amended the law and made the scheme simpler and more attractive.
The Opposition make the charge that in these days the Government allow only wretched boxes to be built in place of houses. Do hon. Members opposite never go into modern council houses or flats? I have been into a good many newly built houses and flats lately in different parts of England and Wales. I was in some new flats last week in two London boroughs, one under Socialist
and the other under Conservative control—Finsbury and Kensington. They were not boxes. They were not cramped. They were charming flats, and all the tenants said how delighted they were to have got them.
I want to pay a tribute to what local authorities are doing for the old people. In the years after the war we did not build enough for them. We naturally had to build mostly for families. The result was that when the Labour Government went out of office only 7 per cent. of the council houses and flats being built were designed for old people. Now the figure is about 20 per cent., and I hope that it will go up to 25 per cent. Is that what the Opposition criticise when they seek to debate local authority housing?
We want the others, too.

The hon. and learned Member says that he wants the others, too. The truth is that once again the Opposition are censuring the Government for building too many houses. This time their case is that they are not the right sort of houses. Half the houses now being built are houses which people are choosing to live in for themselves.
The Opposition case is quite simple. The right hon. Gentleman has reduced the rate of council housing. He has nearly halved it in the course of five years. Why?

I have another ten minutes, and I have ten minutes' worth to say. We think it is a good thing that houses should be built both through private enterprise and through public authorities. The Opposition do not; they imagine that all our people want to live in council houses. They will find that they are mistaken. The vast majority of our people want to live in houses of their own. It is for the people who cannot make their own arrangements that the councils must build.
Between 1945 and 1951 the people who could and would make their own arrangements for housing were not allowed to do so, because that was contrary to Socialist philosophy. We got rid of the Socialist housing controls on private building, and the Socialists said that this would cut down council house
building. It did not. Council house building expanded as soon as the Conservatives came into power. In England and Wales, in the five years from 1947 to 1951 public authorities built 707,000 houses—an average of 141,000 a year. In the last five years, from 1954 to 1958, no less than 807,000 have been built—an average of 161,000 a year. Are the Opposition so ashamed of their record that they are censuring us for building only 20,000 a year more than they did?
Slum clearance has been referred to. The Labour Government did not attempt it. It is not possible to carry out large scale slum clearance if a Government is content with a small building programme. That is why, as my hon. Friend the Member for Glasgow, Pollok (Mr. George) said, the only two great slum clearance drives in history have been under Conservative Governments. We gave a pledge before the General Election. We said that we would aim at rehousing 200,000 people a year. We have not only aimed at it, we have done it. We hope to do it again in 1959, and 1960 too, provided there is not the disaster of a change of Government.
This summer I have been making it my business to get around and see for myself slum clearance and redevelopment in different towns. I have been to some of the oldest towns which grew up in the early days of the Industrial Revolution. I have been to places like Merthyr and Oldham. Last week I went round London, and tomorrow I shall be in Wolverhampton, so I say to the hon. Lady the Member for Wood Green that I do not need further opportunities to see how people are living.
Conditions in which thousands of people are still having to live in this country are shocking. During the last week I have been to houses where the sanitary facilities have to be seen to be believed, and sometimes, as everybody who visits slum property knows, one goes into a house where there is a brooding depression of evil over the whole house. I am the first to say that bad housing produces viciousness and vice. These houses must come down, and the quicker the better. As long as the Conservative Government remain in office we shall continue our programme until every house that is not fit for human habitation is pulled down.
In the meantime, the landlords are allowed to charge more rent.
The hon. Gentleman is ignorant even in his interruption. He should know that under the Rent Act it is not possible to charge more rent.
The right hon. Gentleman is showing his ignorance. Under the Rent Act, rents in Scotland went up without any condition at all about improvement to the houses.
Answer.
I will certainly answer for England. In England the Rent Act is one of the most powerful instruments for improving the condition of houses which otherwise would deteriorate.
If the right hon. Gentleman comes to Newcastle I will show him houses which are utterly disgraceful but where the rents have been increased.

If the hon. Gentleman has allowed people in his constituency to pay increased rents for houses which are not fit for habitation, with respect to him, he has been failing in his duty as a Member of Parliament.
The Opposition asked for this debate. They have chosen the date for the debate. It is the date on which the latest housing figures are those for the first four months of 1959. The total number of new houses started in the first four months of this year is higher than in the corresponding period of any year since the war, bar two. I need hardly say that both of those other years were when a Conservative Government were in power. But the gravamen of the Opposition's charge seems to be that the Government are making it impossible for local authorities to build. Let us examine that.
The number of council houses and flats built is governed by the approval of tenders. Every local authority has to submit its tenders to the Ministry and get them approved. The Committee is perfectly entitled to know how the approval of tenders has proceeded. Here, I think, we come to the real crux of the criticism of the Opposition. In the first four months of 1950, when a Labour Government were in power, the number of houses in tenders approved
by the Government for public authorities in England and Wales was 40,098. In 1951, the last year of the Labour Government, it was 42,145. Now the housing need is not so extensive as it was then—[HON. MEMBERS: "Oh."]—as 2¼ million houses have been built under a Conservative Government meantime, and 1½ million of those are council houses and houses built by public authorities.
Under our Government, nearly twice as many houses have been built by public authorities than at any time under the Labour Government. Nevertheless, despite this enormous improvement in the situation, the figures for tenders approved in the first four months of 1959, the current year, was more than in

either 1950 or 1951. So, as usual, the Conservative Government are doing better than the Labour Government did. I realise that hon. Members opposite find that difficult to bear. I am now going to wait with interest to see whether the Opposition really will dare to go into the Lobbies to censure the Government for having a better housing policy and a finer housing record than theirs.
In response to the Minister's challenge, I beg to move, "That Item Class V, Vote 1 (Ministry of Housing and Local Government) be reduced by £5.
The Committee divided: Ayes 241, Noes 299.
